issuetype.description: Created by Jira Software - do not edit or delete. Issue type for a user story.
issuetype.name: Story

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
status.name: Open

content.text: Problem:
Per our SDLC process pull requests must have a Jira ticket.  If there is no active Jira ticket the developer is supposed to supply a ticket prefix and -0+.
Example:  PMPINTERCO-0 or PMPGATEWAY-0000
The ASK:
Please when a user creates a Pull request in Jira. Check the Pull request title,
Create a github action that will check  the PR title.  Parse out the Jira ticket tags, call the Jira API and check that the ticket  :
Exists and is in one of the following status:  'Ready For Release”,  “Ready For Test”, “In Test”,  “In Progress”.
If the issue does not exist in Jira it should have a -0+ number.
Contains release/YYMM-a|b|c with optional -#
Possible Regex:
/(?:PMPGATEWAY|PMPINTERCO|AHCP|HPS|HPSERV|BLUE|CLEAR|CLOUD|PMPAWARE)-?\d+/gi
If possible fail to create the PR and supply a message as to why the PR could not be created.
If it fails, write a comment on the PR saying why it failed.  “Example PMPCLEAR-1234 is Done, cannot merge code to that ticket.”  Please re-write your commit message.

fields.summary: GIT ACTION to check for jira tags

content.text: - Here is the ticket we talked about.  I am thinking, if possible, we should key off of the PR title rather than the commit messages themselves.  Because that is something the user creating the PR can change right there without having to re-write the git history.      Which would make it way easier on the user.  Since all of our commits pretty much require a PR that should be enough.
But If that is not possible we could still go with the commit messages.
Update:

Based on the reading, it’s not possible to deny the creation of the PR. It is also not possible to force the PR into a draft. Seemingly the creation of a PR is noted to be an ‘atomic operation’ and then the workflows and such of GitHub actions kick off.
However, it looks like it is possible to call the Github API to create a “review” on a PR.

We could auto-create a review on a PR that was created seemingly by creating an action that would do that. This should reject the ability to merge without addressing the review as our current settings are made to do. When someone says “changes requested” it usually blocks the merge.
returning a non-zero status code, should cause the workflow to be represented as a failure. Which should fall into the use case of requiring all checks to pass before merge.
Good point, I forgot about that. But it still doesn’t mean the PR won’t get created. So yes, we should already get the failed ‘check’ technically and won’t need anything more complicated than that.
you can define multiple triggers for the action.

However, since we’re validating and checking commit messages, and force push is disabled on remote, the only solution to resolve bad commits, is to close the PR, delete the branch from remote, rebase, and try again.
I wonder if force push can be allowed on feature/ and bugfix/ branches. Then you would redo the workflow on updates

I read some article suggesting that we could close the PR automatically through a GitHub-API call, however that would probably just stock up a bunch of dead PRs for bad pushes and we probably don’t need that kind of thing.
Your point about force push is possible. The docs I’m seeing in GitHub suggest you can put a branch protection rule with allow force push for specific people.
